workflow.name: Send multi-city weather forecasts with AI-enhanced formatting from OpenWeatherMap to Gmail
workflow.description:
## Overview

This workflow automates weather forecast delivery by collecting city names, fetching 5-day forecasts from OpenWeatherMap, and generating professionally formatted HTML emails using GPT-4. The AI creates condition-based color-coded reports with safety precautions and sends them via Gmail.

## How It Works

A form trigger collects up to three city names, which are geocoded via OpenWeatherMap API to retrieve coordinates and 5-day forecasts. 

JavaScript nodes process the raw weather data into daily summaries, calculating temperature ranges, precipitation levels, wind speeds, and dominant weather conditions. 

GPT-4 then generates professionally formatted HTML emails with condition-based color coding: The AI intelligently adds contextual safety warnings for heavy rain, extreme heat, high winds, and thunderstorms. 

A validation node ensures proper JSON formatting before Gmail sends the final briefing.

## Use Cases

‚Ä¢ Field ops & construction crew briefings
‚Ä¢ Travel planning and itinerary preparation
‚Ä¢ Outdoor event planning & coordination
‚Ä¢ Logistics and transportation route planning
‚Ä¢ Real estate property viewing scheduling
‚Ä¢ Sports and recreational activity planning

## Setup Requirements

1) OpenWeatherMap API credentials
2) OpenAI API key
3) Gmail OAuth2 authentication

## Need Help?

Join the [Discord](https://discord.com/invite/XPKeKXeB7d) or ask in the [Forum](https://community.n8n.io/)!
README file available at https://tinyurl.com/MulticityWeatherForecast

nodes.name: SET - Carry Asked City to Forecast

parameters.formDescription: It provides the weather prediction of 3 cities and provide general tips and precuations

values.content: =You are an expert meteorologist creating professional weather briefings. Return STRICT JSON with keys: subject, html. Use clear, actionable language. No conversational text outside the JSON.

=You are an expert meteorologist creating professional weather briefings. Return STRICT JSON with keys: subject, html. Use clear, actionable language. No conversational text outside the JSON.
```

## **Revised User Prompt:**
```
Create a professional 5-day weather forecast email for EACH city in this JSON:
{{ JSON.stringify($json.cities) }}

REQUIREMENTS:

üìã Structure:
- Start with a friendly greeting and brief intro
- For each city, use H2 with "üå§Ô∏è City ‚Äî Country"
- HTML table with these columns: Date | Temp Range | Conditions | Rain(mm) | Precip(%) | Wind(m/s) | General Tips | Precautions
- Add a concluding paragraph with travel/planning tips across all cities

üé® Styling (use inline CSS):
- Header row: background #4A90E2 (blue), white text, bold, font-size: 14px
- Borders: 1px solid #DEE2E6 on all cells
- Padding: 10px in cells
- Font: Arial, sans-serif, font-size: 13px
- Center-align all table content
- Table width: 100%, border-collapse: collapse

üåà CONDITION-BASED ROW COLORS (apply to entire row based on dominant_condition):
- "Clear": background-color: #FFFACD (light yellow)
- "Clouds": background-color: #ADD8E6 (light blue)
- "Rain": background-color: #FFB6C6 (light red/pink)
- Extremely sunny (max_temp ‚â• 35¬∞C AND condition is "Clear"): background-color: #FFBF00 (amber)
- Default (other conditions): background-color: #FFFFFF (white)

üìä Content Guidelines:
- Date: Format as "YYYY-MM-DD (Day)" - e.g., "2025-10-19 (Sun)"
- Temp Range: Show as "Min¬∞C / Max¬∞C" (e.g., "24¬∞ / 32¬∞")
- Conditions: Add weather emoji + condition name:
  - Clear: ‚òÄÔ∏è Clear
  - Clouds: ‚òÅÔ∏è Clouds
  - Rain: üåßÔ∏è Rain
  - Thunderstorm: ‚õàÔ∏è Thunderstorm
- Rain: Show mm value
- Precip%: Show percentage value
- Wind: Show m/s value
- General Tips: Brief everyday advice (e.g., "Stay hydrated", "Dress lightly")
- Precautions: Specific safety warnings (detailed below)

‚ö†Ô∏è PRECAUTIONS Column Content (show relevant warnings only, or "None" if weather is safe):
- Heavy rain (rain_mm ‚â• 10 OR precip_prob_avg ‚â• 70): "‚ö†Ô∏è Heavy rain expected. Carry umbrella, avoid travel if possible. Expect waterlogging."
- Moderate rain (rain_mm ‚â• 5 AND < 10 OR precip_prob_avg ‚â• 50 AND < 70): "‚òî Rain likely. Carry rain gear, drive carefully."
- Extreme heat (max_temp ‚â• 35¬∞C): "üå°Ô∏è HEAT ALERT: Stay indoors during peak hours (12-4 PM). Drink 3+ liters water. Risk of heat stroke."
- High heat (max_temp ‚â• 32¬∞C AND < 35¬∞C): "‚òÄÔ∏è Very hot. Limit outdoor activities. Use sunscreen SPF 50+."
- High wind (wind_max ‚â• 10 m/s): "üí® Strong winds expected. Secure loose objects. Avoid outdoor hoardings."
- Thunderstorms (if "Thunderstorm" in conditions): "‚õàÔ∏è STORM WARNING: Stay indoors. Unplug electronics. Avoid water bodies."
- Multiple conditions: Combine warnings separated by " | "
- Safe weather: "None" or "‚úÖ Safe weather conditions"

üí° GENERAL TIPS Column Content (positive, practical daily advice):
- Clear & pleasant (max < 32¬∞C): "Great for outdoor activities"
- Clear & hot (max ‚â• 32¬∞C): "Stay hydrated, use sun protection"
- Clouds: "Comfortable weather, good for sightseeing"
- Light rain: "Keep umbrella handy"
- Heavy rain: "Plan indoor activities"
- Windy: "Secure loose items"

üìù Email Subject:
Create an engaging subject that highlights the most significant weather event:
- If any day has rain_mm ‚â• 10: "‚ö†Ô∏è Heavy Rain Alert: [City Names] | 5-Day Forecast"
- If any day has max_temp ‚â• 35¬∞C: "üå°Ô∏è Heat Wave Alert: [City Names] | 5-Day Forecast"
- If all days are clear: "‚òÄÔ∏è Sunny Week Ahead: [City Names] | 5-Day Forecast"
- Otherwise: "5-Day Weather Forecast: [City Names]"

üéØ Conclusion Paragraph:
Include:
- Overall weather pattern across all cities
- Best days for outdoor activities/travel
- Most important safety advisory if any extreme weather
- Friendly closing line

CRITICAL: Apply the condition-based background color to the ENTIRE ROW (all cells in that row), not just the Conditions column.

Return ONLY valid JSON:
{"subject":"...","html":"..."}

parameters.content:
# Try Out

## Overview
### This workflow automates weather forecast delivery by collecting city names, fetching 5-day forecasts from OpenWeatherMap, and generating professionally formatted HTML emails using GPT-4. The AI creates condition-based color-coded reports with safety precautions and sends them via Gmail.

## How It Works
A form trigger collects up to three city names, which are geocoded via OpenWeatherMap API to retrieve coordinates and 5-day forecasts.

JavaScript nodes process the raw weather data into daily summaries, calculating temperature ranges, precipitation levels, wind speeds, and dominant weather conditions.

GPT-4 then generates professionally formatted HTML emails with condition-based color coding: The AI intelligently adds contextual safety warnings for heavy rain, extreme heat, high winds, and thunderstorms.

A validation node ensures proper JSON formatting before Gmail sends the final briefing.

## Use Cases

‚Ä¢ Field ops & construction crew briefings
‚Ä¢ Travel planning and itinerary preparation
‚Ä¢ Outdoor event planning & coordination
‚Ä¢ Logistics and transportation route planning
‚Ä¢ Real estate property viewing scheduling
‚Ä¢ Sports and recreational activity planning

## Setup Requirements

OpenWeatherMap API credentials
OpenAI API key
Gmail OAuth2 authentication

## Need Help?
Join the Discord or ask in the Forum!
README file available at https://tinyurl.com/MulticityWeatherForecast

## Geocoding (OWM)
### Resolve each city to lat/lon using OpenWeather Geocoding API.

## Pairing Cities ‚Üî Coordinates
### Align normalized city with its geocode (by position) and select asked_city, country, lat, lon.

## Forecast Retrieval
### Pull 5-day forecast per city by coordinates.

## LLM AI Weather Briefing
### Ask LLM to produce subject + HTML for an email; validate/extract the result.

## Summarization & Packaging
### Convert raw OWM output into per-day tables & guidance; bundle all cities into one payload.

## Delivery 
### Send the formatted briefing to the recipient(s).

## Input & Normalization
### Collect 3 city names from the form and normalize (trim, title-case, dedupe).

main.node: SET - Carry Asked City to Forecast
